org.mellowtech.core.bytestorable.io

Class SortedBlock<T extends BComparable<?,T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.mellowtech.core.bytestorable.io.SortedBlock<T>
  • Deprecated.

    @Deprecated
public class SortedBlock<T extends BComparable<?,T>>
extends Object
    The SortedBlock keeps a sorted byte array of ByteStorables. The SortedBlock divides the byte array into two sections, the first section is the pointers to the actual keys stored in the array. All sorting, searching, rearranging is done in the pointers section. Thus, keys does not have to be physically sorted in the block, it is only the pointers that are sorted. The SortedBlock do not have to be defragmented. Whenever keys are deleted the SortedBlock automatically move that space to the unused space section. So using very long keys with heavy insert/delete can reduce performance.

    The overhead for using the SortedBlock depends on the pointer size. It can either be 4, 2, 1 byte extra for each key stored in the sorted block.
    Author:
    Martin Svensson

      • setBlock

        public SortedBlock<T> setBlock(byte[] block,
                               T keyType,
                               boolean newBlock,
                               byte ptrSize,
                               short reservedSpace)
        Deprecated. 
        Set the block to work with.
        Parameters:
        block - the physical block to store keys in
        keyType - The type of keys that this block handles
        newBlock - Indicate wheter this is a new block.
        ptrSize - The size of the pointers in this block. If the normal pointer size is used this block can store up to 32000 keys
        reservedSpace - X bytes will be reserved for caller to use freely (for instance for specific header information).

      • setBlock

      • sort

        public SortedBlock<T> sort(boolean parallelSort)
        Deprecated. 
        If the keys in this block has been inserted unsorted use sort to sort the contents. This method works as follows:
        it reads in every key into an CBytalbe[], and then either calls Arrays.sort or sort.
        If you are reading in many keys at once it is a good idea to first store them in an array than call sort, and then insert them using insertUnsorted into this block.
        Parameters:
        parallelSort - If true use Arrays.parallelSort, otherwise use Arrays.sort
        See Also:
        sort(boolean), insertKeyUnsorted(T)

      • splitBlock

        public SortedBlock<T> splitBlock()
        Deprecated. 
        Splits a block in two. The new block will contain the upper half of this block's keys. The resved space is also copied
        Returns:
        A SortedBlock with keys greater than this block's keys

      • storageCapacity

        public int storageCapacity()
        Deprecated. 
        The actual storage capacity of this sortedblock. Remember that Each key stored will have an additional number of bytes for its pointer.
        Returns:
        storage in bytes

      • updateKey

        public void updateKey(T key,
                      int index)
        Deprecated. 
        This will update a previously stored key. Use with caution since it will just overwrite the current data at the given index. Thus, the keySize cannot have changed.
        Parameters:
        key - a value of type 'ByteStorable'
        index - a value of type 'int'
